CORYDON.</br>Nowe Tityrus, since wee at ease are lade,</br>And both our flockes orespred the flowrie plaine:</br>Sweete friend unfolde under this platen shade</br>The secrete cause of thy concealed paine,</br>How haps thy sighing threats the cleered skie,</br>With gentle Zephyr waging often warres,</br>Whose Muse of yoare with hunnie melodie,</br>Did calme fierce winds, and cease their boistrous jarres?</br>What means this moorning weed?  thy weeping eine?</br>thy pale aspect?  thy murmuring complaints?</br>Speake, that I may joine my teares with thine,</br>and ease thy burdened heart before it faints.

TITYRUS.</br>Corydon forbeare by deepe inquire</br>To rip the skarred wounds of my unrest:</br>No teares, no counsell can abate the fire,</br>Which loving sorrow kindles in my brest.</br>I all alone in darkesom unkoth place,</br>I all alone must like the Turtle Dove,</br>Whose joy is slaine, bewaile my wretched case,</br>And powre out plaints agenst the gods above,

CORYDON.</br>By sylvane nymphs, and lovely Graces three,</br>That on our lawnes doe sport them to and fro;</br>By countrie powres of what so ere degree;</br>By Floraes chaplet; by Dianaes boe,</br>By fruitfull Pales, Ceres wheaten crowne,</br>By silver Thamesis old Oceans dame;</br>By chang'd Amintas flow'r, that decks the downe;</br>And lastlie by Elisaes vertuous name,</br>By these, and those that guide caelestial spheares,</br>I here conjure thee to discloase thy griefe,</br>That I maie slake thy sighing with my teares,</br>Whose comforts oft have bred my harts relief.

TITYRUS.</br>Then thus (though loath) as griefe will suffer me,</br>My faltring tongue shall tell my discontent:</br>That cares by sympathie maie worke on thee,</br>And thou upholde some part of my lament.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife</br>Sweet Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.</br>Now Corydon (for evrie shepheard swaine</br>Reports thee skilfull in a sacred verse)</br>In such a meeter helpe me to complaine,</br>As maie befit great Meliboeus hearse.

CORYDON.</br>I now beginne:  Apollo guide my sounde,</br>And weepe yee sisters of the learned hill:</br>That your Paegasean springs may leap their bound,</br>And from their floate maie seas of teares distill.</br>Let deadly sorrow with a sable wing,</br>Throughout the world go brute this tragedie:</br>And let Arcadians altogether sing</br>A woefull song agenst heavns tirannie.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife</br>Sweet Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

Are wheeling orbs so full of foule despight,</br>That neither wisdome, nor true pietie,</br>Nor learned skill, nor speech of choice delight,</br>Nor care of countries sweete securitie,</br>Nor watchfull studie for Dianaes health,</br>Nor gentle birth which vertues worth did raise,</br>Nor honors titles, nor abundant wealth,</br>Nor thousand gifts deserving endlesse praise</br>Could smooth the mallice of old Saturnes brow,</br>Or heate of Mars, or Lunaes deathfull colde:</br>O envious heavns, that winde I wotte not how,</br>Grudging the glories of this earthly molde.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife:</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

Yet glorious heavns, O pardon my blaspheme,</br>Whose witte in sorrowes Labyrinth is straide:</br>All that I spake was but a furious dreame,</br>It was not you, but Fates that him betraide.</br>O thou eternall Monarcke, at whose becke</br>The planets moove and make their influence:</br>O give the Destinies a wrathfull checke,</br>Afflict them for their spightfull insolence.</br>In case mine oraison seeme overlarge,</br>O yet vouchsafe me but this one request,</br>That fatall lawes be givn to Saintes in charge,</br>Whose hands and harts wil alwaies work the best.</br>What can those Imps of everclowding mist,</br>Those ruthlesse daughters of eternall night;</br>But (tyrantlike) sunder their vitall twist,</br>Whose shining vertues are the worldes chiefe light?</br>Alas too soone by destins fatall knife,</br>Sweet Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

And was not Astrophill in flowring prime,</br>By cruell Fates cut off before his daie,</br>Yong Astrophill, the mirrour of our time,</br>Faire Hyales chiefe joy, till his decay?</br>When late a dreadfull Lyon in his pride</br>Descended downe the Pyraenaean mount,</br>And roaring through the pastures farre and wide,</br>Devowr'd whole Belgian heards of chief account:</br>Stout Astrophill incenst with sole remorse,</br>Resolv'd to die, or see the slaughter ceast:</br>Then senst with fire and sword, with manly force</br>He made assalt upon the furious beast.</br>But of this tale teares drowne the latter part:</br>I must returne to Meliboeus fall,</br>Who mourning still for Astrophils depart,</br>Forsooke his friends, and lost himselfe withall.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife,</br>Sweet Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

Nowe tell me shephards all, and fellow swaynes,</br>Who shal with rampiers fence our country foile?</br>And keep the fluds from breaking ore the plaines?</br>And sheild our tender flocks from deadly spoile?</br>Who shall recure their faintie maladies,</br>And purge their fleeces in soft running streams?</br>Who shall defend our lambs from jeoperdies?</br>And shrowd our kids from Titans parching beames?</br>Who now shal til our ground, and reape our corne?</br>Who shall assuage the strife of swelling pride,</br>When evrie swynard shall exceede his borne,</br>And will not by God Terminus be tyde?</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife,</br>Sweet Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

TITYRUS.</br>Thy tunes have often pleas'd mine eare of yoare,</br>When milk-white swans did flocke to heare thee sing,</br>Where Seane in Paris makes a double shoare,</br>Paris thrise blest if shee obey her King.</br>But now O Corydon, that lightsome vaine</br>Is changd from youth to aged gravitie,</br>That whilst I heare thee bitterlie complaine,</br>Ne thinks Apollo sings in Arcadie.</br>And yet afford thy moorning Muse some reft,</br>While I (though skil and voice are both decaide)</br>With termes of duetie from a pensive brest</br>Bewaile my friend, whom cruell Fates betraide.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

O all that all the Univers containes</br>In heavn, or aire, or earth, or watrie deepe;</br>With mutual plaints make light my secret pains,</br>For sorrow wasts in teares, where manie weepe</br>And first ye Figures in the Zodiacke line,</br>That decke heavns girdle with aeternall light:</br>O faine some griefs, and knit them unto mine,</br>Such griefs as may this baser worlde affright.</br>Now Cancer slake thy heate with brackish raine,</br>And Leo roare, to make the skie dismaide:</br>Aquarius powre thou downe salt teares amaine,</br>And Aries let thy dancing now be staide.</br>Now Libra make not aequinoctiall,</br>But suffer night to overgrow the daie:</br>Or darkenes fits all us that live in thrall,</br>Let those have light that list to sport and plaie.</br>Now let the Centaure with his poisned steele</br>Upon the Fates inflict a deadlie wounde:</br>That for misguiding late their fatall wheele</br>They may lament with guosts of under-ground.</br>Now let the winter under Capricorne</br>Last still:  and Pisces lend him watrie showres:</br>Let Taurus wound the welkin with his home,</br>And Scorpio with his taile sling fatall powres.</br>Now Gemini forbeare with gladsome shine,</br>To comfort Sea-men in their chiefe dispaire:</br>Virgo make fountains of thy daie-bright eine,</br>And teare the treasure of thy golden haire.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

Yee seavnfold flames, whose ever-circling fires</br>Maintain this earth with influence from your sphears,</br>And with your powre guide mortall mens desires,</br>Now leave your harmonie, and fall to teares.</br>Yet cankred Saturne it were all in vaine,</br>With my intreats to call for thy lament,</br>For if old Orpheus but a sooth have faine,</br>To miseries thy minde is alwaies bent.</br>Thou still art lumpish, waiward, cold, and sloe,</br>Attended on with Terror, doating night,</br>Pale discontent, sighs, discord, teares, and woe,</br>Fit mates for me that want my chiefe delight.</br>But thee faire Jupiter I must require,</br>To change the gratious vertue of thy starre,</br>And not to temper with thy gentle fire, </br>The raging heates of him that breedeth warre.</br>Let Mars roave uncontrold and kindle strife,</br>That Sorrowes may sit downe by Slaughters side:</br>And golden Sol surcease to favour life;</br>And Venus weepe, as if Adonis dide.</br>And Stilbon with thy hatt cloude Phoebus face,</br>And Luna see thou steale no more his beames:</br>But let thy Steedes forbeare their nightlie race,</br>And from thy bosome powre downe weeping streames.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatal knife,</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

Now Aire, and what thy circuites doe containe,</br>Helpe to lament great Meliboeus death:</br>Let clouds of teares with sighs be turnd to raine,</br>Admit no winde but evergroaning breath.</br>Now set thy firie Pyramids to viewe,</br>Thy divers Idols, Candles burning bright:</br>Inflamed Shafts, Comets of dreadfull hewe;</br>Sparkles that flie, and Starres that fall by night.</br>Let all thy Meteors, of what ever kinde,</br>With terror sort them selves in just araie:</br>And worke such fear in every mortall minde,</br>That all the world may waile for ones decade.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatal knife,</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

CORYDON.</br>Tityrus thy plaint is overlong,</br>Here pause a while, at Corydons request:</br>Of what is wanting in thy farfet song,</br>My moorning voice shall strive to tell the rest.</br>But I must sorrow in a lower vaine.</br>Not like to thee, whose words have wings at wil:</br>An humble stile befits a simple Swaine,</br>My Muse shall pipe but on an oaten quill.</br>Immortall Fauns, Satyrs, and great Pan,</br>The Gods and guiders of our fruitfull soile,</br>Come seat your selves by me, and waile the man,</br>Whose death was hastned by his vertuous toile.</br>Yee comelie Graces neither dance nor plaie,</br>Nor kembe your beauteous tresses in the Sun,</br>But now since Meliboeus is awaie,</br>Sit downe and weepe, for wanton daies are dun.</br>Now in the woods be leafelesse evry Tree,</br>And beare not pleasant fruits as heretofore:</br>Myrrha let weeping gums distill from thee,</br>And help to make my dolefull plaint the more.</br>Now in the woods let night-ravns croak by daie,</br>And gladies Owles shrike out, and Vulturs grone:</br>But smaller birds that sweetly sing and play,</br>Be whist and still:  for you can make no mone.</br>Now in the fields each corne hang down his head,</br>Since he is gon that weeded all our corne:</br>And sprouting Vines wither till you be dead,</br>Since he is dead, that shielded you from storme.</br>Now in the fields rot fruits while you are greene,</br>Since he is gon that usde to graff and grace you:</br>And die faire flowres, since he no more is seene,</br>That in Dianaes garland used to place you.</br>O heards and tender flocks, O handsmooth plains,</br>O Eccho dwelling both in mount and vallie:</br>O groves and bubling springs, O nimphs, O swains.</br>O yong and olde, O weepe all Arcadie.</br>Alas too soone by Destins fatall knife</br>Sweete Meliboeus is depriv'd of life.

TITYRUS.</br>O let me interrrupt thee yet once more,</br>For who should more lament his losse then I.</br>That oft have tasted of his bounteous store,</br>And knew his secret vertues perfectlie?</br>We have alreadie summond everie part,</br>Excepting that which in the Ocean lies:</br>To stand copartners of our wofull smart,</br>And beate the senselesse aire with Elegies.</br>Now therfore Neptune grant me this one boone,</br>Depose great Jove for so misguiding fate:</br>That Meliboeus wounded all too soone,</br>By Mortaes malice dies before his date.</br>And thou old Glaucus with divining blest,</br>Prophet to him that never speakes but truth,</br>Come with Palaemon, Phorcus, and the rest,</br>And here give oracle of endles rush.</br>Come Tethis come with Thetis after thee,</br>And all thy watrie nymphs, a lovelie traine:</br>Vouchsafe to sit upon these bankes with me,</br>That I may heare both thee and them complaine.</br>And thou great Triton with thy sounding shell,</br>Impart my grievance unto everie shore:</br>And with a murmure make the waves goe tell,</br>That worthie Meliboeus breaths no more.</br>Now let no Dolphins seeke Arions Muse,</br>Nor play by shore to ketch up heedles boies:</br>Let them suppose sweete Musicke out of use,</br>And wanton lovetricks to be foolish toies.</br>Deceitfull Mermaids leave your auncient guise,</br>Forbeare to sing while tempest troubles us:</br>Let me behold whole fountains in your eies,</br>For weeping sits unhappie Tityrus.

CORYDON.</br>But Tityrus inough, leave of a while:</br>Stop moorning springs, drie up thy drearie eine,</br>And blithlie intertaine my altred stile,</br>Inticd from griefs by some allure divine.</br>For now my mind reclaimd from carefull mone,</br>Gins fault hir giving place to sorrows sourse:</br>And in hir change intreats thee cease to grone,</br>That as we grievd, so we may joie by course.</br>In just complaint though sorrowes were begun,</br>And all too litle for the man we waile:</br>Yet now at last our sorrows must be done,</br>And more then moorning reason must prevail.</br>Injustlie grudge we Meliboeus death,</br>As though his worth were buried in his fate:</br>But neither are his vertues drenchd in Leath,</br>Nor vertuous soule removd to meaner state:</br>His faith hath framd his spirit holie wings,</br>To soare with Astrophil above the Sun:</br>And there he joies, whence every comfort springs,</br>And where the fulnes of his blisse begun.</br>Let us be joifull after long annoie,</br>Since Meliboeus livs in perfect joie.</br>Our Meliboeus livs where Seraphins</br>Doe praise the Highest in their glorious flames:</br>Where stowes the knowledge of wise Cherubins:</br>Where Throans exhibit earthlie deeds and names</br>Where Dominations rule and yet obaie:</br>Where Principalities to lower powers</br>Deepe hidden misteries doe still bewraie:</br>Where arms are usd by foe-subduing powers.</br>Where Vertues practise miracles and wunder:</br>Where both Archangels and sweet Angels sing,</br>Whose office is, to us, that live here under,</br>From heavn caelestiall messages to bring.</br>Let us be joifull after long annoie,</br>Since Meliboeus livs in perfit dole.</br>Now Meliboeus in comparelesse place,</br>Drinkes Nectar, eates divine Ambrosia;</br>And hath fruition of eternall grace,</br>And with his countnance cheeres Arcadia.</br>Then while his spirit dwels in heavnlie towres,</br>Let us performe what honor dutie willes:</br>Let us adorne his sacred tumb with flowres,</br>And sweete it with the riches of our hilles.</br>Our vernall Flora that bewailes our losse,</br>Will gladlie let hir flowrie locks be rent:</br>And clad hir selfe in moornfull roabes of mosse,</br>If all the treasure of hir buds were spent.</br>Then Flora lends us thime and violets,</br>Sweete balme and roses for his buriall:</br>Bestow no wealth on wanton amorets,</br>But spare it to adorne his funerall.</br>And Pales bath his lims in fluds of milke,</br>And cover him with costly ornament:</br>Inshrine his corps in sheetes of softest silke,</br>For he deservs Mausolus monument.</br>And Tityrus let us before the rest set holie lights,</br>And watch his breathles corse,</br>Singing sweet himns for him whose soule is blest,</br>Though parted from his flesh by deaths divorce.</br>Now cheere we Dryas in hir miserie,</br>Who overlong bewailes hir haplesse case:</br>Lest overloving like Laodamie,</br>Shee loose hir selfe in deepe supposd imbrace.</br>Now call we Hyale from whispring streames,</br>Increast with teares (true servants of annoie)</br>Who takes no pleasure but in griefs extreames,</br>Nor joies in ought but in hir want of joie:</br>Faire Hyale, who wringing oft hir armes,</br>Hir armes far whiter then Sythonian snoa,</br>With doubling sighs bewails hir helples harmes,</br>Alas that helples harmes should vexe hir so.</br>Yet beuteous Nymph thy carefull mother lives,</br>(Long may shee live, and living ease thy hart)</br>Accept what comfort hir surviving gives,</br>And in lifes comfort drown thy sorrows smart.</br>Helpe thou with us, and evrie countrie wight,</br>To chace all grievance from Dianaes minde:</br>From drad Diana, earths and heavns delight,</br>Diana, glorie of hir sexe and kinde;</br>Diana, wondrous mirrour of our daies;</br>Diana matchlesse Queene of Arcadie;</br>Diana, whose surpassing beauties praise</br>Improovs hir worth past terrene deitie;</br>Diana, Sibill for hir secret skill;</br>Diana, pieties chief earthlie friend;</br>Diana, holie both in deede and will;</br>Diana whose just praises have no end.</br>Ah but my Muse, that creeps but on the ground,</br>Begins to tremble at my great presume,</br>For naming hir, whose titles onelie found</br>Doth glad the welkin with a sweet perfume.</br>For in hir minde so manie vertues dwell,</br>As evrie moment breed new pieties:</br>Yet all in one cojoind doe all excell,</br>And crowne hir worth with sundrie deities.</br>But that unwares my sorie stile proceeds</br>Drad Cynthia pardon:  love desires dispense:</br>As Joves high Oaks orelook Pans slender reeds,</br>So bove all praising flies thine excellence.</br>Yet lest my homespun verse obscure hir worth,</br>Sweet Spencer let me leave this taske to thee,</br>Whose neverstooping quill can best fet forth</br>Such things of state, as passe my Muse, and me.</br>Thou Spencer art the alderliefest swaine,</br>Or haply if that word be all to base,</br>Thou art Apollo whose sweet hunnie vaine</br>Amongst the Muses hath a chiefest place.</br>Therefore in fulnes of thy duties love,</br>Calme thou the tempest of Dianaes brest,</br>Whilst shee for Meliboeus late remove</br>Afflicts hir mind with overlong unrest.</br>Tell hir forthwith (for well shee likes thy vaine)</br>That though great Meliboeus be awaie:</br>Yet like to him there manie still remaine,</br>Which will uphold hir countrie from decaie.</br>First name Damoetas, flowre of Arcadie,</br>Whose thoughts are prudent, and speech vertuous,</br>Whose looks have mildnes joind with Majestie,</br>Whose hand is liberall and valorous:</br>He is Damoetas; that is wont to blame</br>Extreamest justice voice of equitie:</br>Diana terms him by an other name,</br>Hatton, unlesse I faile in memorie.</br>The name old Damon, whom shee knows of old</br>For such as Nestor was to Graecians guide:</br>Worth ten of Ajax, worth all Croessus gold,</br>If his deserts in ballance could be tride.</br>Damon is he that counsels still aright,</br>And heedfullie preservs Dianaes store:</br>And wakes when others rest them selvs by night,</br>We Arcads cald him Cecill heretofore.</br>Then name brave Aegon, that with ships defence</br>About our coast orespreds the Ocean plaines,</br>To keepe fell monsters of the sea from hence:</br>We cleape him Howard, that are countrie swaines.</br>Name Mopsus, Daphnis, Faustus, and the rest,</br>Whose sevrall gifts thy singing can expresse:</br>When thou shalt tell how shee in them is blest,</br>Their verie names will comfort hir distresse.

TITYRUS.</br>Castor and Pollux, Loedaes lovelie twins,</br>Whose bright aspect cheers moornful Mariners,</br>Shewing them selves when pleasant calme begins,</br>Of gladsome newes two welcome messengers,</br>Convey great comfort to the weltred minde,</br>And with their sheen appearance breed delight:</br>Yet Corydon thy leare and love combinde</br>Please more by healing, then those twain by sight,</br>For they portending stormie windes surcease,</br>But by portending cause the hearts content:</br>Thy learnd persuades command my sorrow cease,</br>And sweetnes doth allure to merriment.</br>But hie we homeward, night comes on apace,</br>Weel learne belive forget our doleful notes:</br>See where faire Venus shewes hir radiant face,</br>Lets hence, and shut our sheepfolds in their coat.</br>
